code_examples.explanation: The original `MultiFunctionDevice` interface forced all implementing classes to provide methods for printing, scanning, and faxing, even if they couldn't perform all functions. The refactoring separates these functionalities into distinct interfaces, adhering to the ISP by allowing classes to implement only the methods they actually support.

The original `PortalUser` interface was too large and forced all implementing classes to provide methods that were irrelevant to their roles. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, role-specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). Each class now only implements the methods relevant to its functionality.

The original `MusicPlayer` interface was too large, forcing `VinylPlayer` to implement methods that were not applicable to it, violating the ISP. The refactored code splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces, allowing classes to implement only the methods they need.

The original `Vehicle` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the functionalities into smaller, more specific interfaces (`Drivable`, `Flyable`, and `Divable`), allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to their behavior.

The original `DeviceControl` interface was too large, forcing classes to implement methods that were not applicable to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces: `DeviceControl`, `VolumeControl`, and `Lockable`, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to their functionality.

The original `Character` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to all character types, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code splits the responsibilities into smaller, more specific interfaces, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to them.

The original interfaces forced both `Chef` and `Waiter` to implement methods that were irrelevant to their roles, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the responsibilities into two distinct interfaces, allowing each class to implement only the methods that are relevant to their specific roles.

The original `Shape` interface included methods for calculating volume, which is not applicable to all shapes (e.g., Circle, Rectangle, Line). This refactoring separates the volume calculation into a new `VolumetricShape` interface, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP) by ensuring that classes only implement methods that are relevant to them.

The original interfaces forced `SmartSpeaker` to implement a method (`setScreenResolution`) that was irrelevant to it, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code introduces a new interface `FirmwareUpdatable` for devices that can update firmware, allowing `SmartSpeaker` to implement only the methods it needs.

The original interfaces combined multiple responsibilities, forcing classes to implement methods that were not relevant to their functionality. By splitting `UIStyleAndAnimation` into separate `UIStyle` and `UIAnimation` interfaces, we adhere to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP), allowing classes to implement only the methods they need.

The original interfaces combined multiple unrelated methods, forcing implementations to provide functionality they did not need. The refactored code separates the interfaces into smaller, more specific ones, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original interfaces combined multiple responsibilities, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the interfaces into distinct ones for flight booking, booking management, payment processing, and notifications, allowing classes to implement only the interfaces they need.

The original `MultiFunctionDevice` interface forced all implementing classes to provide methods for printing, scanning, and faxing, even if they did not support all functionalities. The refactored code separates these responsibilities into distinct interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original design forced all user types to implement methods that were irrelevant to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the responsibilities into distinct interfaces, allowing each user type to implement only the methods that are applicable to them.

The original `MusicPlayer` interface included methods that were not applicable to all implementations, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactoring separates the `skip_track` and `eject` methods into their own interfaces, allowing classes to implement only the methods they need.

The original `Vehicle` class forced all subclasses to implement methods that were not applicable to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code introduces separate interfaces for driving, flying, and diving, allowing each vehicle to implement only the methods relevant to its functionality.

The original `DeviceControl` interface included methods that were not applicable to all devices, leading to unnecessary implementations in classes like `RegularLightBulb` and `SmartLock`. The refactoring separates the interface into three distinct interfaces: `DeviceControl`, `VolumeControl`, and `Lockable`, ensuring that classes only implement the methods relevant to their functionality, thus adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `Character` interface forced all subclasses to implement methods that were not applicable to all character types, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code introduces smaller, more specific interfaces for each behavior, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to them.

The original `RestaurantWorker` and `MealPreparation` interfaces were too large, forcing classes to implement methods that were not relevant to their responsibilities. The refactoring separates the interfaces into smaller, more focused ones, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original code violated the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) because subclasses like `Circle`, `Rectangle`, and `Line` implemented a `calculate_volume` method that was not applicable to 2D and 1D shapes, leading to warnings and potential misuse. The refactored code introduces a new abstract class `TwoDimensionalShape` that extends `Shape`, allowing 2D shapes to inherit from it while raising `NotImplementedError` for volume calculations, thus adhering to LSP.

The violation was due to the `MultimediaDevice` interface requiring methods that are not applicable to all devices, such as `set_screen_resolution` for `SmartSpeaker`. By creating a separate `FirmwareUpdatable` interface, we ensure that only devices that require firmware updates implement that functionality, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

code_examples.input:
from abc import ABC, abstractmethod

class UIComponent(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def render(self): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def resize(self, width, height): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_visible(self, visible): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_background(self, color): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_foreground(self, color): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def on_click(self, x, y): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def on_hover(self, x, y): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def on_key_press(self, key_code): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def on_focus(self): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def on_blur(self): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def add_child(self, child): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def remove_child(self, child): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def get_parent(self): pass

class UIStyleAndAnimation(ABC):
    @abstractmethod
    def set_font(self, font_name, size): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_text_alignment(self, alignment): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_margin(self, top, right, bottom, left): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def set_padding(self, top, right, bottom, left): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def fade_in(self, duration_ms): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def fade_out(self, duration_ms): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def slide_in(self, direction, duration_ms): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def slide_out(self, direction, duration_ms): pass
    @abstractmethod
    def stop_animations(self): pass


class Button(UIComponent, UIStyleAndAnimation):
    def __init__(self, label, x, y, width, height):
        self.label = label
        self.x, self.y, self.width, self.height = x, y, width, height
        self.background_color = "#CCCCCC"
        self.foreground_color = "#000000"
        self.parent = None

    def render(self):
        print(f"Rendering button: {self.label}")

    def on_click(self, x, y):
        print(f"Button clicked: {self.label}")

    def set_background(self, color):
        self.background_color = color

    def set_foreground(self, color):
        self.foreground_color = color

    def resize(self, width, height):
        self.width = width
        self.height = height

    def set_visible(self, visible): pass
    def on_hover(self, x, y): pass
    def on_key_press(self, key_code): pass
    def on_focus(self): pass
    def on_blur(self): pass
    def add_child(self, child): pass
    def remove_child(self, child): pass
    def get_parent(self): return self.parent

    def set_font(self, font_name, size): pass
    def set_text_alignment(self, alignment): pass
    def set_margin(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def set_padding(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def fade_in(self, ms): pass
    def fade_out(self, ms): pass
    def slide_in(self, dir, ms): pass
    def slide_out(self, dir, ms): pass
    def stop_animations(self): pass

class TextField(UIComponent, UIStyleAndAnimation):
    def __init__(self, initial_text, x, y, width, height):
        self.text = initial_text
        self.x, self.y, self.width, self.height = x, y, width, height
        self.focused = False
        self.parent = None

    def render(self):
        print(f"Rendering text field: {self.text}")

    def on_key_press(self, key_code):
        print(f"Key pressed in text field: {key_code}")

    def on_focus(self):
        self.focused = True
        print("Text field focused")

    def on_blur(self):
        self.focused = False
        print("Text field lost focus")

    def resize(self, width, height):
        self.width, self.height = width, height

    def set_visible(self, visible): pass
    def set_background(self, color): pass
    def set_foreground(self, color): pass
    def on_click(self, x, y): pass
    def on_hover(self, x, y): pass
    def add_child(self, child): pass
    def remove_child(self, child): pass
    def get_parent(self): return self.parent

    def set_font(self, font_name, size): pass
    def set_text_alignment(self, alignment): pass
    def set_margin(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def set_padding(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def fade_in(self, ms): pass
    def fade_out(self, ms): pass
    def slide_in(self, dir, ms): pass
    def slide_out(self, dir, ms): pass
    def stop_animations(self): pass

class Image(UIComponent, UIStyleAndAnimation):
    def __init__(self, path, x, y, width, height):
        self.path = path
        self.x, self.y, self.width, self.height = x, y, width, height
        self.parent = None

    def render(self):
        print(f"Rendering image from: {self.path}")

    def resize(self, width, height):
        self.width, self.height = width, height
        print(f"Image resized to: {width}x{height}")

    def fade_in(self, ms):
        print(f"Fading in image over {ms}ms")

    def fade_out(self, ms):
        print(f"Fading out image over {ms}ms")

    def set_visible(self, visible): pass
    def set_background(self, color): pass
    def set_foreground(self, color): pass
    def on_click(self, x, y): pass
    def on_hover(self, x, y): pass
    def on_key_press(self, key_code): pass
    def on_focus(self): pass
    def on_blur(self): pass
    def add_child(self, child): pass
    def remove_child(self, child): pass
    def get_parent(self): return self.parent

    def set_font(self, font_name, size): pass
    def set_text_alignment(self, alignment): pass
    def set_margin(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def set_padding(self, t, r, b, l): pass
    def slide_in(self, dir, ms): pass
    def slide_out(self, dir, ms): pass
    def stop_animations(self): pass

class Panel(UIComponent, UIStyleAndAnimation):
    def __init__(self, x, y, width, height):
        self.children = []
        self.parent = None
        self.x, self.y, self.width, self.height = x, y, width, height
        self.margin = [0, 0, 0, 0]
        self.padding = [0, 0, 0, 0]

    def render(self):
        print("Rendering panel")
        for child in self.children:
            child.render()

    def resize(self, width, height):
        self.width, self.height = width, height
        print(f"Panel resized to: {width}x{height}")

    def set_visible(self, visible):
        print(f"Panel visibility set to: {visible}")

    def add_child(self, child):
        self.children.append(child)
        print("Child added to panel")

    def remove_child(self, child):
        self.children.remove(child)
        print("Child removed from panel")

    def get_parent(self): return self.parent

    def set_margin(self, t, r, b, l):
        self.margin = [t, r, b, l]
        print("Panel margins set")

    def set_padding(self, t, r, b, l):
        self.padding = [t, r, b, l]
        print("Panel padding set")

    def set_background(self, color): pass
    def set_foreground(self, color): pass
    def on_click(self, x, y): pass
    def on_hover(self, x, y): pass
    def on_key_press(self, key_code): pass
    def on_focus(self): pass
    def on_blur(self): pass
    def set_font(self, font_name, size): pass
    def set_text_alignment(self, alignment): pass
    def fade_in(self, ms): pass
    def fade_out(self, ms): pass
    def slide_in(self, dir, ms): pass
    def slide_out(self, dir, ms): pass
    def stop_animations(self): pass
code_examples.explanation: The original code had a single interface that combined UI component functionality with styling and animation methods, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates these concerns into three distinct interfaces: `UIComponent`, `UIStyle`, and `UIAnimation`, allowing classes to implement only the interfaces relevant to their functionality.

The original code violated the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) because subclasses of `NotificationSender` and `NotificationReceiver` raised `NotImplementedError` for methods they did not support, breaking the expected behavior of the base class. The refactored code introduces a `not_supported` method to handle unsupported services uniformly, ensuring that subclasses can be substituted without breaking the contract.

The original `FlightBookingService` and `NotificationService` interfaces contained methods that were not relevant to all implementations, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the booking-related methods into a new `BookingService` interface, ensuring that classes only implement the methods they actually use.

The original `MultiFunctionDevice` interface forced all implementing classes to provide methods for printing, scanning, and faxing, even if they couldn't perform all functions. The refactored code separates these functionalities into distinct interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `PortalUser` interface was too large, forcing implementations to provide methods that were not relevant to all users. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `MusicPlayer` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to all types of music players, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the responsibilities into smaller interfaces, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to them.

The original `Vehicle` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the interfaces into `Drivable`, `Flyable`, and `Divable`, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to their functionality.

The original `DeviceControl` interface was too large, forcing classes to implement methods that were not applicable to them (like `volumeUp`, `volumeDown`, and `lock`). The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `Character` interface was too large, forcing all implementing classes to provide methods that were not applicable to all character types. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). Each character class now only implements the interfaces relevant to its capabilities.

The original interfaces forced both `Chef` and `Waiter` to implement methods that were irrelevant to their roles, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the responsibilities into two distinct interfaces, allowing each class to implement only the methods relevant to their specific roles.

The original code violated the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) because the `calculateVolume` method was implemented in 2D shapes (Circle, Rectangle, Line) in a way that did not make sense, leading to warnings. The refactored code introduces a new interface `ThreeDimensionalShape` for shapes that can calculate volume, ensuring that only appropriate shapes implement this method.

The violation was due to the `MultimediaDevice` interface forcing `SmartSpeaker` to implement the `setScreenResolution` method, which is not applicable to speakers. By creating a separate `FirmwareUpdatable` interface, we ensure that only devices that require firmware updates implement that functionality, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original code had a single interface `UIComponent` that combined multiple responsibilities, leading to an interface that forced implementing classes to provide methods that were not relevant to all components. The refactoring separates the concerns into three distinct interfaces: `UIComponent`, `UIStyle`, and `UIAnimation`, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original implementation violated the Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) because subclasses of `NotificationSender` were throwing exceptions for methods they did not support, which breaks the expected behavior of the base class. The refactored code introduces an abstract class `BaseNotificationSender` that provides default implementations for unsupported methods, allowing subclasses to only implement the methods they support without violating LSP.

The original `FlightBookingService` interface included methods that were not relevant to all implementations, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the booking-related methods into `CustomerBookingService` and `AdminBookingService`, ensuring that classes only implement the methods they need.

The original `MultiFunctionDevice` interface forced all implementing classes to provide methods for printing, scanning, and faxing, even if they couldn't support all functionalities. The refactored code separates these responsibilities into distinct interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `PortalUser` interface was too large and forced all implementing classes to provide methods that were not relevant to their roles. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, role-specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `MusicPlayer` interface was too large, forcing `VinylPlayer` to implement methods that were not applicable to it, such as `skipTrack` and `eject`. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces, adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `Vehicle` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to them, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the interface into three distinct interfaces: `LandVehicle`, `AirVehicle`, and `WaterVehicle`, allowing each class to implement only the methods relevant to its functionality.

The original `DeviceControl` interface was too large, forcing classes like `RegularLightBulb` and `RGBLightBulb` to implement methods that were not applicable to them. The refactoring splits the interface into smaller, more specific interfaces (`VolumeControl` and `Lockable`), allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to their functionality, thus adhering to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP).

The original `Character` interface forced all implementing classes to define methods that were not applicable to all character types, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code introduces smaller, more specific interfaces for each behavior, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to them.

The original interfaces forced both `Chef` and `Waiter` to implement methods that were irrelevant to their roles, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the responsibilities into two distinct interfaces, allowing each class to implement only the methods that are relevant to their specific roles.

The original `IShape` interface forced all shapes to implement methods for both 2D and 3D calculations, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the interfaces into `IShape2D` and `IShape3D`, allowing classes to implement only the methods relevant to their shape type.

The original interfaces `NetworkDevice` and `MultimediaDevice` included methods that were not applicable to all implementing classes, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The `SetScreenResolution` method in `MultimediaDevice` was unnecessary for `SmartSpeaker`, which does not have a screen. The refactored code removes this method from the interface, ensuring that classes only implement methods that are relevant to them.

The original code had a single interface `IUIComponent` that combined multiple responsibilities, including rendering, event handling, and styling/animation methods. This violated the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the styling and animation methods into their own interfaces (`IUIStyle` and `IUIAnimation`), allowing classes to implement only the interfaces relevant to their functionality.

The original interfaces forced implementing classes to provide methods that were not relevant to their functionality, violating the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP). The refactored code separates the notification methods into distinct interfaces, allowing classes to implement only the methods they need.

The original interfaces `IFlightBookingService` and `INotificationService` were too large, forcing classes to implement methods that were not relevant to their responsibilities. By splitting `IFlightBookingService` into `IFlightBookingService` and `IBookingService`, we adhere to the Interface Segregation Principle (ISP), allowing classes to implement only the methods they need.
